title: Monday, 2nd November, 2015

11:07 am
PM

an investigational fully human monoclonal antibody inhibitor of plasma kallikrein being developed for the prevention of hereditary angioedema (HAE) attacks.

BE

I already know about DX-2930 for the prophylaxis of HAE, as in hereditary angioedema

PM

Oh do you

11:07 am
PM

omg smile

BE

I know for example that Shire's existing prophylaxis treatment for HAE does a $1B run-rate

BE

So this is a future-proofing type acquisition

11:08 am
BE

With the potential for DX-2930 to go into other indications

PM

Hereditary angioedema (types I, II and III) (also known as "HAE") is a rare, autosomal dominantly inherited blood disorder that causes episodic attacks of swelling that may affect the face, extremities, genitals, gastrointestinal tract and upper airways

PM

Sounds nasty

11:09 am
BE

Makes a lot of sense, particularly with DX-2930 given FDA approval back in July

BE

11:10 am
BE

Basically, Every $100M cut in sales for Cinryze reduces Shire EPS by 1%

BE

Historic stuff from Jefferies to explain the moving parts.

BE

If DX-2390 continues to post very positive
clinical results and receives approval, it could likely disrupt the HAE market. In our view,
despite DX-2390’s likely superiority vs. Cinrzye, we do not believe that Kalbitor poses much
of a threat to Firazyr for the reasons stated above. For illustrative purposes, we denote
the possible impact to SHPG’s financials if DX-2390 were to cannibalize Cinryze’s sales.
Specifically, we model $945M/$1015M/$1077M for Cinryze from FY18-20, which is ~10%
of total revs each year. If DX-2390 takes 33% of Cinryze sales in FY18 then revs/EPS would
decline ~3%/2%. Looked at another way, every $100M reduction in Cinryze sales in FY18
corresponds to a ~1% decline in EPS, according to our model. In the most extreme case,
if we were to completely remove Cinryze from our forecast starting in FY18, sales would
decline ~10% and EPS would decrease ~8% from FY18-20 – assuming constant R&D and
SG&A margins.

BE

11:12 am

11:18 am
BE

And generic took basically no share whatsoever. As in, sub 1%.

BE

Today, we get another warning on it.

BE

Here's Cazenove's new forecasts.

11:19 am
BE

This morning Hikma released their Interim Management Statement for
Q3’15. Although the outlook for the branded business has been cut, this
was more than offset by increases to the Injectables guidance. However,
the slow development of colchicine means that generics guidance has been
cut substantially. Overall this leads to downgrades to Consensus FY’15
outlook by 7%. Hence we believe this morning’s share price reaction
is justified.

BE

 New Injectables FY’15 guidance implies a modest upgrade to
Company Consensus of around $11.5m: On Revenues Hikma remain
confident in the guidance of at least maintaining revenues at the very
high level of 2014. For adjusted operating profit Hikma expect to have a
strong 2H'15 adjusted operating margin which we interpret as a margin
of 34%, implying a FY'15 margin of 38%. At this level we see $11.5m
of upside to Company Consensus adjusted operating profit of $259.9m
(Cons. Adj. Op Margin36.4%) on Consensus revenues of $715m.

BE

(@kodojin: it is. Hikma tried to pincer the market with both generic and branded versions and found neither of them sold.)

11:19 am
BE

 New FY’15 reported guidance for the branded division, likely to
lead to Consensus cuts of c. $8m: The guidance remains for growth in
the “low-teens” for revenue and adjusted operating margin to improve
by around 200 basis points, however on a reported basis the revenue
growth is only mid single digits, with a slight improvement in the
adjusted operating margin. With Company Consensus currently looking
for Revenue of $598.6m (+8.6% reported growth) and an adjusted
operating margin boost of 90bp to 21% ($125.8m) we believe that the
new guidance implies a cut in adjusted operating profit of around $8m.

BE

 FY’15 Revenues and Margins cut for the Generics division, implying
a substantial $33m cut to Consensus adjusted operating profit:
Hikma lowered the revenue guidance to $150m (previously ($175-
$200m) which implies large cuts to Consensus revenues for the division
which are currently at $193.8m. In addition, with the guidance for
adjusted operating margin of high twenties, this implies a margin of 28-
29%, substantially below Consensus which was looking for 39.2% As a
result we believe FY’15 Consensus numbers for generics could need to
be cut by $32-33m

BE

 Cuts to Colchicine forecasts required for FY15, although solid
growth in FY16 still expected with improving access. Currently, we
forecast Colchicine sales of $60m in FY15 and $100m in FY16. Despite
cuts to FY15 Colchcine forecasts expected as a result of the guidance
upgrade and weak IMS data (IMS data currently annualizing at c.$20m
in FY15), we still feel Hikma can deliver solid sales growth in FY16 as
they can step up the physician and patient awareness programmes and
their confidence they can improve managed care access.

11:20 am
BE

 Overall changes to group outlook imply a 7% downgrade to current
Consensus forecasts for FY’15. Consensus is currently forecasting
adjusted operating profit of $400m, based on an overall cut of around
$30m, we believe Consensus numbers will have to come down by 7%

BE

 Roxane timing delayed slightly deal. The circular for the Roxane deal
will down be send out in December (prev. November) suggesting the
deal closing is delayed by around 1 month. The deal is expected to close
in the next 3 months, so the latest time is now January 2016.

BE

And for a quicker summary .... Jefferies.

11:21 am
BE

US Generics guidance lowered: Hikma has lowered guidance for its US Generics division
due to slower than expected growth in colchicine sales as the company has shifted its
strategy to a hybrid branded and generic approach. Hikma has adjusted its guidance from
$175-200m to $150m (JEFe $209m) and the company expects an adjusted operating margin
for 2015 to be “in the high twenties” vs. JEFe 34%. Hikma expects Mitigare to grow in 2016
given its ability to improve managed care access. We note that the legacy products within
the business have continued to perform well.
CER Branded growth is strong: In CER terms the business is “performing well”, with a
recovery in Algeria, good demand in other GCC markets and Egypt. However, FX volatility
and political disruption have affected operations in Iraq and Sudan. For the FY Hikma
expects Branded revenue growth in the low-teens (CER) and adjusted operating margin to
improve by around 200bps (CER). On a reported basis the company expects “mid-single
digit” revenue growth vs. “high single-digit” at 1H (JEFe +9%) and a “slight improvement” in
adjusted operating margin (JEFe 20.8% in 2015 vs. 20.1% in 2014).
Injectables momentum is positive: The US continues to benefit from improving mix,
and the transfer of Bedford products to Hikma’s global manufacturing facilities is ahead of
schedule. Thiotepa was launched in September and phentolamine gained a recent approval
with launch expected in November, making it the third Bedford launch this year. We note
that phentolamine was approved from its Portuguese facility despite the warning letter still
being in place, which we take as a positive sign for the eventual outcome. In MENA the
company has seen strong growth at CER, highlighting Algeria, Saudi Arabia and Europe.
Hikma remains “positive in its revenue outlook for 2015 and beyond" and expects to achieve
“a strong adjusted operating margin” in H2.

11:33 am
BE

First take - in-line PBT but revenue weakness key concern. Revenues
were 5% light of consensus at $14.0bn (weak Asian RBWM Global Markets)
and given the clean c.$13bn (ex-Brazil) run rate we see risk to consensus for
c.$60bn revenues in 2017. Cost progress was encouraging (-$400m -6% q/q)
shows plan actions bearing fruit and target of 2017 exit run-rate inline with
2014 reiterated. Impairments were benign (19bps ex-Brazil) and capital build
with CET1 ratio +0.2% q/q to 11.8% shows steady progress.

BE

Q3 adjusted operating profit $5.51 billion 2% below consensus
expectations. Group revenues were 5% below consensus at $14.04 billion
and down 9% q/q. However, costs were 4% ahead of consensus at $8.58 billion
and down 6% q/q and impairments were benign at $638 million, down $231
million vs. 2Q15. Below the line charges in the quarter totaled $456 million
including restructuring costs of $165 million, $135 million in legal provisions
and UK customer redress at $67 million.

BE

Revenue miss driven by RBWM and GBM. RBWM revenues were -10% vs
MSe and -13% q/q on lower Asian wealth management revenues and lower
OOI in the UK with private banking revenues also soft (-10% q/q, 8% miss vs.
MSe). GBM revenues were a 6% miss vs. MSe and down 14% q/w with global
markets revenues -22% vs. MSe and -31% q/q and -21% y/y with particular
weakness in credit and rates (down 28% and 55% respectively y/y).
Commercial banking was broadly in line with expectations, -1% q/q. No
indication in the release on outlook, will be a focus for the call.

11:34 am
BE

Encouraging progress on costs. Adjusted costs fell $400 million q/q with
progress shown in RBWM ($130 million reduction) and GBM ($80 million
reduction). Cost guidance has been updated for FX developments with 2017
exit quarterly run rate now guided to $7.6 billion ex. bank levy. This compares
to pre-results consensus for 2017 underlying costs ex. bank levy of $31.6
billion.

BE

Impairment trends benign with write backs in UK. Group impairment
charge ex Brazil was 19bps vs. 26bps in 2Q15. Asia impairments were lower
q/q at $119 million with company flagging "no significant impact from China
slowdown". New slide on China exposure details $96 billion exposure to
mainland China (by country of booking), of which $53 billion loans and
advances to customers and banks.

BE

CET1 ratio +20bps q/q with progress on RWA rundown. $32 billion of
gross RWAs were taken out in the quarter ($11 billion in commercial banking,
$19 billion GBM and $2 billion US run off), taking YTD progress on RWA
reductions to $82 billion with $5 billion of redeployment in the quarter ($27
billion YTD). RWA target updated to c.$275 billion (from c. $290 billion) due to
FX movements.

11:37 am
BE

(@Mo: I think the 400k estimate came from Doctors for the Environment, an NGO.)

BE

And Merrill.

BE

HSBC reported net profit of $5.5bn which was comfortably ahead of forecasts -
something of a relief that a major global bank can produce a decent set of results in
what has hitherto generally been a dismal quarter. BofAML Underweight-30% senior
CDS at +67bps.
Bottom line
Revenues were in fact lower across the board but were particularly impacted by lower
Wealth Management in HK and lower FICC, the latter being a feature of the sector this
quarter. Costs helped, coming in lower than expectations. The cost-income ratio was
54.4%.
Issues to consider
• YTD, the ROTE (stated) is a respectable 12.1%.
• CET1 edged up to 11.8%, closer to where we think HSBC needs to be. Internal
capital generation plus 'RWA initiatives' more than offset the dividend, RWA
growth and FX effects to deliver this higher ratio.
• No evidence of any impact from any slowdown in China this quarter. Asian
provisions were 0.13% compared to 0.19% in 3Q14. Exposure to China is $96bn
of which $53bn in loans. The exposure to HK is $635bn, with RE being a big chunk
of that. We see limited read-across to Standard Chartered as the banks are so
different. We note significant speculation in the UK weekend press (e.g. The
Sunday Times) on the results of SC and the possibility of a capital increase.
• LatAm provisions were comparatively well behaved too (ex Brazil which is being
sold) at 2.17% versus 3% the previous year.
• The bank may take until next year to decide on its domicile, so we may have to
wait for the 4Q report next year for more details. There have been several
concessions by the UK Government to accommodate global banks like HSBC.

11:38 am
BE

And, oh, Nomura too.

BE

HSBC has missed on an underlying basis, with headline numbers propped
up by USD 1.1bn gain on own debt amongst other items. Pre-provision
profits missed by 7% or USD 0.4bn, as revenue weakness (5% miss, USD
0.7bn weaker) was offset partly by costs (4% beat, USD 0.3bn lower).
Underlying PBT came in at USD 5512mn versus consensus of USD 5653mn
– a 2% miss, driven mainly by a 23% beat on the impairments line.
We expect these results to lead to downgrades, as we had expected prior to
results. Even prior to accounting for miss, we were USD 1.4bn or 5% below
2017 consensus pre-provision profits. That said, some of the weakness is
already reflected in the 2HTD performance.
We see HSBC making a c11% ROTE by 2018, with higher rates adding to
this over time. So expect HSBC to trade at just over 1x P/TB in the medium
term before investors give it benefit for growth. Dividends are the main
source of support for the stock and management are well aware of that.
Despite that, dividends could still be at risk depending on macro-economic
environment. That said, current yields are at a very attractive level (before
adjusting for scrip). We expect the stock to be range bound in the near term,
with risks to the downside.

11:46 am
BE

That's from 2010, note. Not the year before when they were all over-levered.

BE

Here's the upshot of it.

BE

We expect 2016 to be another year of improved profitability and strong
operating conditions for the UK housebuilders. We see little risk either of
either earnings downgrades, or of news flow that would meaningfully
impact expectations for longer-term returns. While the sector is 38% up
year to date, we still see an average 14% upside potential. At this stage we
see most value in the small-caps. We upgrade Crest Nicholson to
Overweight (20% upside) and downgrade Barratt Developments to Neutral
(+9%) and Persimmon to Underweight (+3%), as a relative valuation call.

11:46 am
BE

 We struggle to see the land market becoming tougher any time soon,
meaning we expect margins and returns to remain strong: We
continue to believe that the land market dynamics and strong demand
environment driving current strong returns are likely to persist, meaning
we believe the current average RoE of 20% is sustainable and has
upside, despite the historical average being only 15%.

BE

 We see the risk to short-term earnings as being weighted to the
upside: Our estimates continue to be predicated on weaker housing
market conditions than the lead indicators currently suggest.

 We see more value in the small cap stocks: We see an average of 8%
upside to the FTSE 100s, vs. 20% for the small caps. While we continue
to expect the large caps to drive stronger average returns, from what we
view as lower-risk operating models, we still believe the small caps trade
at an excessive discount (1.6x p/tNAV vs. 2.2x).

BE

 We upgrade Crest Nicholson to Overweight and downgrade Barratt
to Neutral and Persimmon to Underweight: We now see 20% upside
potential to Crest vs. only 9% for Barratt and 3% for PSN. We expect
Crest to continue to drive earnings growth and improvement in ROCE
via what we view as a relatively low-risk, high-volume growth strategy.
While our views on the outlook for both Barratt and PSN remain
positive, we currently view both stocks as relatively fully valued.

11:52 am
BE

Whilst the Company is not in a position to verify the assertions in the Notice (as no claim has been received as yet), the Notice estimates the value of the potential claims against the Company to be a maximum of approximately £9 million before costs (if awarded). There can be no guarantee that other claims will not be made against the Company and, in particular, the claimant firm details that it has been approached, but not retained, by other potential claimants who together, it asserts, would have a claim of a maximum value of a further £9 million.

The Company is not aware, and has not been made aware, of any other law firms acting for (or in the process of forming) other claimant groups.

The Notice provides little detail on the potential claim or the timing of the pre-action Letter of Claim and no information to support the valuation of the individual prospective claimants' claims, which would require to be proved in due course in any litigation. At this stage, the Company will vigorously defend all such claims, as appropriate.

Neither the Notice nor any claim made as currently outlined in the Notice would adversely impact the Company's previously announced intentions regarding a capital return.

11:56 am
BE

We expect the banks to only recognise the cash component with expected completion of the deal around Q2 2016. BARC, as expected has the largest share amongst the UK banks. We model BARC to hold ~10% of the shares in VISA Europe with RBS, LLOY and HSBC in the 3-4% ballpark. BARC will report a £400m profit by Q2 2016 and the others should be around half of that.

BE

The full deal represents ~19bps of CET1 for BARC as of Q3 although the nature of the deal will not allow them to realise the full amount while the preferred stock holding will also marginally increase RWAs. The CET1 impact of BARC for 2016 from this deal should be ~10bps.

BE

So, yeah, small beer for Barclays. About £400m. Less for the rest, as in around £200m.

12:00 pm
PM

Tactically we think the AKP’s thumping victory is likely to boost markets to year-end as the strength of the single party majority is likely to provide enough near-term political clarity to alleviate pressure on the currency & rates (and by default equity). But will the AKP use this strength to allow Turkey to find some political stability and economic recovery after a hugely damaging two-year election cycle? Or will it leverage this mandate to institutionalise its power and pursue an executive presidency via a 2016 constitutional referendum? We think avoiding a referendum, reduced polarisation, and evidence of credible choices for key economic policy makers including the central bank governor, will be crucial to sustaining any market recovery into 2016.

PM

Short term the market wins, but not mid-term if we have a 2016 referendum

If the AKP jumps straight into a constitutional referendum to seek an executive presidency, we think Turkey’s damaging two-year election cycle will continue. If so, Turkey’s needed sentiment recovery and windfall gains from low oil will remain on hold, in our view. But with 49.4% of the vote, the AKP is just shy of enough popular support to definitely win a referendum and it has fallen short of the 330 MPS required to call a referendum. Additionally with such a strong single-party majority, President Erdogan’s ability to exert power is less dependent on the technical powers of the presidency and more on his ability to influence the AKP (albeit without provoking a constitutional crisis). While PM Davutoglu’s victory speech sounded like he remains on the campaign trail, we find merit in the argument that it should first seek to reduce instability and return to growth before launching a referendum. Its decision is key.

PM

Economic policy less at risk…but we need the right economic policy makers & central bank governor

If 2016 will not see elections, economic policy should be the biggest winner from the end of the reform stalling two-year election cycle. Economics are rarely a source of ideological conflict in Turkey, but with election after election and a weak economy, demonising the “interest rate lobby” and attacking the central bank became a populist scapegoat. But with the stability buck now stopping with the AKP, we doubt it would want to start off with a tumbling lira & rating downgrades. We expect the central bank and the economic reformists within the government to be left to do their jobs…initially. The question then simply is will there be enough senior economic reformers? The roles of Ali Babacan & Mehmet Simsek and the reform agenda will be key. It will also be important that the election era “interest rate lobby” bashers aren’t enfranchised with proper economic power. As the most widely desired reform from investors is a less politicised central bank, how the government handles the choice of governor in April will be crucial.

12:00 pm
PM

TRY weak enough for exporters…sentiment has been the problem

While much depends on how the AKP responds to its strong mandate, economically Turkey is probably more capable of benefitting form a sentiment shift than perceived. CBT policy is complicated, but with a persistent 10.75% overnight rate, we think it’s tight enough for current inflation/growth and there’s plenty of rate differential with the US. Yes, exports are weak, but that’s largely on dollar strength and demand contraction in key export markets. Double-digit export growth to the EU shows Turkish exports are competitive. If the politics stabilise, we think a weaker lira isn’t likely unless the dollar appreciates sharply vs the euro. The banks have all been more expensive than current price to book levels at least 92% of the time since 2005 and they’re clearly winners of sentiment boost to year end. Migros is our favourite fundamental pick post its ownership change while its heavy euro debts arguably make it a big beneficiary of reduced currency fears. THY remains a key post-election cyclical pick while DO & CO is our favourite structural play on THY’s growth and Gubre on Iran. One sector we’d avoid is autos as we expect volumes to fall in 2016 & high VW imports.
